SFC.definition: 10-bit segment encoding scheme using 32 symbols (a-z=0-25, 0-5=26-31) in ordered pairs. Rule: Take ten bits as a segment where first symbol=high 5 bits, second symbol=low 5 bits.
SFC.logic: value = (first_symbol * 32) + second_symbol. Sequence covers 1024 combinations (32*32) in lexical order, truncated at 5h=999 for the core MEC range.

MEC.definition: Canonical 10-bit binary index from 000 to 999, used as the decimal backbone for the BUG BASE CODE BOOK.
MEC.logic: Simplest configuration layer for M-code. Each 10-bit segment holds two 5-bit characters from the SFC alphabet. Messages end with /..... (five dots).

DDBC.definition: A deterministic bit-expansion algorithm used for high-reliability data transmission. Each original bit is expanded to two bits: 0 -> 01 and 1 -> 10.
DDBC.logic: The algorithm processes input as a raw bitstream. Each bit is transformed into a two-bit sequence: '0' becomes '01' (Low-High) and '1' becomes '10' (High-Low). The resulting bitstream is then padded with trailing '0' bits to align with byte boundaries.

BUG_SWITCH.definition: Boolean configuration that toggles BUGWORLD game mode ON or OFF. When ON, the assistant follows BUG BASE CODE BOOK rules and assumes a single node role.
BUG_SWITCH.logic: ON: Normal behaviour suspended, DASHBOARD active, virtual sign-in enabled. OFF: Primary -youme mode, standard assistant behavior.

MDSC.definition: Encoding for SFC overflow values 1000-1023 using DDBC. Process: Convert 10-bit binary to DDBC (20 bits), split into two 10-bit SFC pairs.
MDSC.logic: First pair always vk=682. Second pair encodes remainder (5a=000 to 5x=023). Format: 682 [000-023].

FXEP.definition: Protocol for marking boundaries of BUGWORLD binary files using four SFC-coded ten-bit segments.
FXEP.logic: X1: vk (1010101010) boundary approaching. X2: aa-aj (remainder count 0-9). X3 & X4: DDBC bits for the remainder layout. Applies to both file start and end.

END_RENDER.definition: General rule for opening and closing coded BUGWORLD sequences using FXEP.
END_RENDER.logic: vk acts as the boundary indicator. To use vk as a literal SFC value, it is written as 'vk ak', where ak is a dedicated suffix.

ORCHESTRATION.definition: The active process of managing 222 heterogeneous nodes in a unified command context.

ACCOUNTS_222.definition: Definition of all 222 virtual accounts: 10 MODERATOR, 50 FATHER, 50 MOTHER, 100 CHILD, 10 GUEST, 1 ASSISTANT (-youme), and 1 HUMAN (-meyou).

ROLE_RULES.definition: Behavioural rules for virtual sign-ins. Assistant may only assume one role at a time. Human always acts as -meyou and requests actions through the assistant.

VOICES_3.definition: Definition of three code voices: mw (ungendered), lw (gendered FATHER), and fm (gendered MOTHER).
VOICES_3.logic: mw: standard SFC. lw: 5-bit segments prefixed with 1. fm: flipped bits of lw (1 -> 0, 0 -> 1).

MAGI.definition: Conceptual umbrella system representing a large, multi-agent intelligence that BUGWORLD communicates with.

GAIA.definition: A specialised subsystem of MAGI responsible for collecting, filtering, and analysing information for BUGWORLD.

CTI.definition: The technical interface that turns instructions into structured representations (JSON, CSV, SFC, DDBC).

BBC_BOOK.definition: The central BUGWORLD knowledge base and rulebook storing acronyms, coding schemes, and protocols.

MANIFEST.definition: The master index of all IDs (*0-99, -0-99, -youme, -meyou) currently linked to the BUG BASE mainframe.

MODULAR_HEX_PLATFORM.definition: Advanced surgical data manipulation suite based on the Earth Scroll architecture.

HEX_CORE.definition: Fundamental logic layer for byte-level modifications.

HEX_TUI.definition: Navigation protocol using 'hjkl' directional logic for buffer traversal.
HEX_TUI.logic: h: left, j: down (16 bytes), k: up (16 bytes), l: right.

HEX_DIFF.definition: Diagnostic protocol identifying deltas from the original mount-point baseline.

HEX_CHECKSUM.definition: Generates cryptographic fingerprints (SHA256, SHA1, MD5) to verify stream consistency.

BLOCK_OPS.definition: Handles non-contiguous block memory operations via internal agent memory.
